Detailed Description

template<class T>
class Kernelizor< T >

Kernelizes pairs of trees by flagging common subtrees and chains in accordance with Rule 1 and Rule 2.

The time complexity is linear.

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

Construct the kernelizor.

Note the default constructor is disabled.

Parameters:

Member Function Documentation

template<class T>
int Kernelizor< T >::chainLinks (  T  label,
T  labels[2]
)  [protected]
 

Use the chain tables to identify common chain neighbours of a leaf.

There are at most two such neighbours. Note that common neighbours from different chains can be cherries in one of the trees and must not be flagged

Parameters:
label Input leaf label whose common links are to be searched for in both trees
labels Output labels of the common chain neighbours if they exist
Returns:
number of chain neighbours in labels.

template<class T>
int Kernelizor< T >::flagChain (  T  label,
T  link
)  [protected]
 

Flag a common subchain in both trees.

Flagged leaves are removed from the chain tables so the never get visited again.

Parameters:
label Label of first leaf in chain
link Label of second leaf in chain

template<class T>
const int * Kernelizor< T >::getLookup (  int  num  )  const [inline]
 

Returns:
a reference to a lookup table corresponding to either t1, t2 or one of the two intermediate trees. Lookup table gives constant access to leaves by label.

template<class T>
int Kernelizor< T >::kernelize (   )  [inline]
 

Kernelize and return number of flagged leaves.

The trees are first processed using Rule 1. The results are then copied into intermediate trees (_t[1] and _t[2]), deleting flagged tokens. Common chains are then flagged ala Rule 2 in these intermeidate trees. The leaves corresponding to these chains are then flagged in the original trees. Throughout all this process, the flags were kept externally in _ftable. At the very end, they are copied back into the trees.

template<class T>
void Kernelizor< T >::loadTree (  UPTree< T > &  tree,
int  num
)  [protected]
 

Copy a reference of the tree into the slot corresponding to num and load all the relevant tables.

template<class T>
size_t Kernelizor< T >::numLeaves (   )  const [inline]
 

Returns:
Number of leaves in the trees

template<class T>
int Kernelizor< T >::rule1 (   )  [protected]
 

Flag all leaves but one in subtrees common to T1 and T2.

This is done by repeatedly flagging common cherries (subtrees with 2 leaves) in linear time.

template<class T>
int Kernelizor< T >::rule2 (   )  [protected]
 

For each common chain c1,c2,c3...,ck in the (intermediate) trees, flag leaves c3,...,ck-1.

This is done by finding endpoints of common chains (leaves with a single common chain neighbour) and walking along the chains flagging as we go.

template<class T>
void Kernelizor< T >::setT1 (  UPTree< T > &  tree  )  [inline]
 

Set first tree of kernelization.

It will be flagged in place by the kernelization but the topology will be unaffected.

template<class T>
void Kernelizor< T >::setT2 (  UPTree< T > &  tree  )  [inline]
 

Set second tree of kernelization.

It will be flagged in place by the kernelization but the topology will be unaffected.
